perturbation.original_text: Schoolpop shall, during the term of this Agreement, at its own cost and expense, procure with sound and reputable insurers, the following insurance coverage's: (i) Workers' Compensation Insurance in an amount not less than the statutory limits for the state(s), country or province in where the services are to be performed; (ii) Employer's Liability Insurance not less than (a) $100,000 per occurrence, and not less than $100,000 aggregate limit of liability per policy year for disease, including death at any time resulting therefrom, not caused by accident or (b) such amount as required by law, whichever is higher; (iii) Comprehensive General Liability Insurance, including blanket extended coverage against all hazards, including personal injury and death resulting therefrom, for not less than $1,000,000 per occurrence, and not less than $2,000,000 aggregate; (iv) Automobile Liability insurance against liability arising from the maintenance or use of all owned, non-owned and hired automobiles and trucks used to provide services, with (a) a minimum limit of liability for bodily injury of $1,000,000 in the aggregate, and with a minimum limit of liability for property damage of $500,000 per accident, or (b) amount as required by law, whichever is higher; and (v) fidelity or crime policy of not less than $3,000,000 in the aggregate against misappropriation and/or destruction of Cards.
perturbation.changed_text: Schoolpop shall, during the term of this Agreement, at its own cost and expense, procure insurance coverage's: (i) Workers' Compensation Insurance in an amount equal to the minimum required. (ii) Employer's Liability Insurance in the minimum required. (iii) General Liability Insurance. (iv) Automobile Liability insurance (v) a crime policy.
perturbation.explanation: The removal of specific coverage amounts and definitions of 'comprehensive' weaken the insurance requirements. This introduces significant legal risk, as Georgia law mandates specific minimum coverage amounts for worker's compensation, employer's liability insurance, general liability insurance, and automobile liability insurance, depending on the nature of the business and the risks involved.  Simply stating "minimum required" or "General Liability Insurance" is insufficient and leaves the contract non-compliant.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Georgia law regarding minimum insurance coverage requirements for businesses, including worker's compensation, employer's liability, general liability, and automobile liability insurance.

perturbation.original_text: Each policy required hereunder shall provide that AEIS shall receive thirty (30) days advance written notice in the event of a cancellation or material change in such policy. Each policy of insurance which Schoolpop is required to possess under this Agreement shall name AEIS, and its Directors, Officers, and Employees, as additional insured in the insurance policy limits herein required. In the event that any service under this Agreement is to be rendered by persons other than Schoolpop's employees, Schoolpop shall furnish AEIS with evidence of insurance for such persons subject to the same terms and conditions as set forth above and applicable to Schoolpop prior to commencement of service by such person(s).
perturbation.changed_text: In the event that any service under this Agreement is to be rendered by persons other than Schoolpop's employees, Schoolpop shall furnish AEIS with evidence of insurance for such persons prior to commencement of service by such person(s).
perturbation.explanation: Removing the requirement for AEIS to receive 30 days' advance written notice of cancellation or material changes to the insurance policy eliminates a critical protection for AEIS. Also, the omission of 'Each policy of insurance which Schoolpop is required to possess under this Agreement shall name AEIS, and its Directors, Officers, and Employees, as additional insured in the insurance policy limits herein required.' significantly reduces the protection provided to AEIS, its directors, officers, and employees. Georgia law generally requires that parties named as additional insureds under a policy are entitled to the same protections and coverage as the primary insured, up to the policy limits.  By omitting this requirement, AEIS exposes itself to potential liability without the assurance of insurance coverage.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Georgia law regarding insurance notification requirements and additional insured status.

perturbation.original_text:
Effective Period One, Schoolpop shall provide full payment of Card funding via wire transfer for Orders placed through the end of Period One. AEIS shall fulfill such Orders upon receipt and clearance of funds.

b.       Effective Period Two, Schoolpop shall provide the full payment of Card funding via ACH Debit at the time Schoolpop requests activation of Cards. AEIS shall activate the Cards by loading the appropriate number of Points onto the Cards as determined by the denomination, and at which time the Cards shall be ready for use by Cardholders within two (2) business days.
perturbation.changed_text:
Effective Period One, Schoolpop shall provide payment of Card funding. AEIS shall fulfill such Orders.

b.       Effective Period Two, Schoolpop shall provide payment of Card funding at the time Schoolpop requests activation of Cards. AEIS shall activate the Cards.
perturbation.explanation: The removal of clear payment methods and timelines introduces ambiguity and creates a legal risk. While it does not explicitly violate a single statute, the lack of defined payment terms can be construed as unfair and deceptive practice, especially if AEIS unilaterally changes payment requirements without agreement.  This ambiguity could be seen as a violation of implied contract law principles requiring good faith and fair dealing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied contract law principles requiring good faith and fair dealing, and potential violations of unfair and deceptive practices acts.
